High severity

Low severity

values.description: Case was resolved
Case was dismissed

friendlyName.description: The graph item display name which is a short humanly readable description of the graph item instance. This property is optional and might be system generated.

additionalData.description: A bag of custom fields that should be part of the entity and will be presented to the user.

accountName.description: The name of the account. This field should hold only the name without any domain added to it, i.e. administrator.

ntDomain.description: The NetBIOS domain name as it appears in the alert format  domain\username. Examples: NT AUTHORITY.

upnSuffix.description: The user principal name suffix for the account, in some cases it is also the domain name. Examples: contoso.com.

sid.description: The account security identifier, e.g. S-1-5-18.

aadTenantId.description: The Azure Active Directory tenant id.

aadUserId.description: The Azure Active Directory user id.

puid.description: The Azure Active Directory Passport User ID.

isDomainJoined.description: Determines whether this is a domain account.

displayName.description: The display name of the account.

objectGuid.description: The objectGUID attribute is a single-value attribute that is the unique identifier for the object, assigned by active directory.

hostEntityId.description: The Host entity id that contains the account in case it is a local account (not domain joined)

dnsDomain.description: The DNS domain that this host belongs to. Should contain the compete DNS suffix for the domain

ntDomain.description: The NT domain that this host belongs to.

hostName.description: The hostname without the domain suffix.

azureID.description: The azure resource id of the VM.

omsAgentID.description: The OMS agent id, if the host has OMS agent installed.

values.description: Host with Linux operating system.
Host with Windows operating system.
Host with Android operating system.
Host with IOS operating system.

osVersion.description: A free text representation of the operating system. This field is meant to hold specific versions the are more fine grained than OSFamily or future values not supported by OSFamily enumeration

isDomainJoined.description: Determines whether this host belongs to a domain.

directory.description: The full path to the file.

fileName.description: The file name without path (some alerts might not include path).

hostEntityId.description: The Host entity id which the file belongs to

fileHashEntityIds.description: The file hash entity identifiers associated with this file

systemAlertId.description: Holds the product identifier of the alert for the product.

confidenceScoreStatus.description: The confidence score calculation status, i.e. indicating if score calculation is pending for this alert, not applicable or final.

values.description: Score will not be calculated for this alert as it is not supported by virtual analyst
No score was set yet and calculation is in progress
Score is calculated and shown as part of the alert, but may be updated again at a later time following the processing of additional data
Final score was calculated and available

intent.description: Holds the alert intent stage(s) mapping for this alert.

values.description: The default value.

Probing could be an attempt to access a certain resource regardless of a malicious intent or a failed attempt to gain access to a target system to gather information prior to exploitation. This step is usually detected as an attempt originating from outside the network in attempt to scan the target system and find a way in.

Exploitation is the stage where an attacker manage to get foothold on the attacked resource. This stage is applicable not only for compute hosts, but also for resources such as user accounts, certificates etc. Adversaries will often be able to control the resource after this stage.

Persistence is any access, action, or configuration change to a system that gives an adversary a persistent presence on that system. Adversaries will often need to maintain access to systems through interruptions such as system restarts, loss of credentials, or other failures that would require a remote access tool to restart or alternate backdoor for them to regain access.

Privilege escalation is the result of actions that allow an adversary to obtain a higher level of permissions on a system or network. Certain tools or actions require a higher level of privilege to work and are likely necessary at many points throughout an operation. User accounts with permissions to access specific systems or perform specific functions necessary for adversaries to achieve their objective may also be considered an escalation of privilege.

Defense evasion consists of techniques an adversary may use to evade detection or avoid other defenses. Sometimes these actions are the same as or variations of techniques in other categories that have the added benefit of subverting a particular defense or mitigation.

Credential access represents techniques resulting in access to or control over system, domain, or service credentials that are used within an enterprise environment. Adversaries will likely attempt to obtain legitimate credentials from users or administrator accounts (local system administrator or domain users with administrator access) to use within the network. With sufficient access within a network, an adversary can create accounts for later use within the environment.

Discovery consists of techniques that allow the adversary to gain knowledge about the system and internal network. When adversaries gain access to a new system, they must orient themselves to what they now have control of and what benefits operating from that system give to their current objective or overall goals during the intrusion. The operating system provides many native tools that aid in this post-compromise information-gathering phase.

Lateral movement consists of techniques that enable an adversary to access and control remote systems on a network and could, but does not necessarily, include execution of tools on remote systems. The lateral movement techniques could allow an adversary to gather information from a system without needing additional tools, such as a remote access tool. An adversary can use lateral movement for many purposes, including remote Execution of tools, pivoting to additional systems, access to specific information or files, access to additional credentials, or to cause an effect.

The execution tactic represents techniques that result in execution of adversary-controlled code on a local or remote system. This tactic is often used in conjunction with lateral movement to expand access to remote systems on a network.

Collection consists of techniques used to identify and gather information, such as sensitive files, from a target network prior to exfiltration. This category also covers locations on a system or network where the adversary may look for information to exfiltrate.

Exfiltration refers to techniques and attributes that result or aid in the adversary removing files and information from a target network. This category also covers locations on a system or network where the adversary may look for information to exfiltrate.
The command and control tactic represents how adversaries communicate with systems under their control within a target network.

The impact intent primary objective is to directly reduce the availability or integrity of a system, service, or network; including manipulation of data to impact a business or operational process. This would often refer to techniques such as ransom-ware, defacement, data manipulation and others.

confidenceScore.description: The confidence score of the alert.

alertDisplayName.description: The display name of the alert.

remediationSteps.description: Manual action items to take to remediate the alert.

confidenceLevel.description: The confidence level of this alert.

values.description: Unknown confidence, the is the default value
Low confidence, meaning we have some doubts this is indeed malicious or part of an attack
High confidence that the alert is true positive malicious

vendorName.description: The name of the vendor that raise the alert.

productName.description: The name of the product which published this alert.

productComponentName.description: The name of a component inside the product which generated the alert.

alertType.description: The type name of the alert.

productVersion.description: The version of the product generating the alert.

processingEndTime.description: The time the alert was made available for consumption.

status.description: The lifecycle status of the alert.

values.description: Unknown value
New alert
Alert closed after handling
Alert dismissed as false positive
Alert is being handled

endTimeUtc.description: The impact end time of the alert (the time of the last event contributing to the alert).

startTimeUtc.description: The impact start time of the alert (the time of the first event contributing to the alert).

timeGenerated.description: The time the alert was generated.

compromisedEntity.description: Display name of the main entity being reported on.

values.description: Unknown hash algorithm
MD5 hash type
SHA1 hash type
SHA256 hash type
SHA256 Authenticode hash type

malwareName.description: The malware name by the vendor, e.g. Win32/Toga!rfn

category.description: The malware category by the vendor, e.g. Trojan

fileEntityIds.description: List of linked file entity identifiers on which the malware was found

processEntityIds.description: List of linked process entity identifiers on which the malware was found.

sid.description: The SID attribute is a single-value attribute that specifies the security identifier (SID) of the group

objectGuid.description: A single-value attribute that is the unique identifier for the object, assigned by active directory.

resourceId.description: The azure resource id of the resource

appId.description: The technical identifier of the application.

appName.description: The name of the related cloud application.

instanceName.description: The user defined instance name of the cloud application. It is often used to distinguish between several applications of the same type that a customer has.

commandLine.description: The command line used to create the process

values.description: Default elevation token
Full elevation token
Limited elevation token

elevationToken.description: The elevation token associated with the process.

creationTimeUtc.description: The time when the process started to run

accountEntityId.description: The account entity id running the processes.

hostEntityId.description: The host entity id on which the process was running

hostLogonSessionEntityId.description: The session entity id in which the process was running

domainName.description: The name of the dns record associated with the alert

ipAddressEntityIds.description: Ip entity identifiers for the resolved ip address.

dnsServerIpEntityId.description: An ip entity id for the dns server resolving the request

hostIpAddressEntityId.description: An ip entity id for the dns request client

address.description: The IP address as string, e.g. 127.0.0.1 (either in Ipv4 or Ipv6)

location.description: The geo-location context attached to the ip entity

threatIntelligence.description: A list of TI contexts attached to the ip entity.

GeoLocation.description: The geo-location context attached to the ip entity

countryCode.description: The country code according to ISO 3166 format

countryName.description: Country name according to ISO 3166 Alpha 2: the lowercase of the English Short Name

longitude.description: The latitude of the identified location, expressed as a floating point number with range of - 90 to 90, with positive numbers representing North and negative numbers representing South. Latitude and longitude are derived from the city or postal code.

latitude.description: The longitude of the identified location, expressed as a floating point number with range of -180 to 180, with positive numbers representing East and negative numbers representing West. Latitude and longitude are derived from the city or postal code.

providerName.description: Name of the provider from whom this Threat Intelligence information was received

hive.description: the hive that holds the registry key.

values.description: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE
HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT
HKEY_CURRENT_CONFIG
HKEY_USERS
HKEY_CURRENT_USER_LOCAL_SETTINGS
HKEY_PERFORMANCE_DATA

entityKind.description: The kind of the aggregated entity.

count.description: Total number of aggregations of the given kind (and aggregationType if given) in the expansion result.

aggregationType.description: The common type of the aggregation. (for e.g. entity field name)

displayName.description: The display name of the aggregation by type.

ODataFilter.name: $filter
ODataFilter.description: Filters the results, based on a Boolean condition. Optional.

ODataTop.name: $top
ODataTop.description: Returns only the first n results. Optional.

ODataSkipToken.name: $skipToken
ODataSkipToken.description: Skiptoken is only used if a previous operation returned a partial result. If a previous response contains a nextLink element, the value of the nextLink element will include a skiptoken parameter that specifies a starting point to use for subsequent calls. Optional.
